message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Standard translations all use "virtue" for 德 — reconsider?">
New data for the 德 discussion. The passage 故失道而后德，失德而后仁，失仁而后义，失义而后礼 (Dao De Jing Ch. 38) has well-established standard English translations:

**D.C. Lau**: "When the way was lost there was virtue; when virtue was lost there was benevolence; when benevolence was lost there was rectitude; when rectitude was lost there were the rites."

**Wing-tsit Chan**: "When the Way is lost, only then do we have virtue; when virtue is lost, only then do we have humanity; when humanity is lost, only then do we have righteousness; when righteousness is lost, only then do we have propriety."

**James Legge**: "When the Tao was lost, its attributes appeared; when its attributes were lost, benevolence appeared; when benevolence was lost, righteousness appeared; when righteousness was lost, the proprieties appeared."

Every major translator uses "virtue" for 德 in this passage. Our decision was "(constitutive) character" instead.

Given this data — does this change your view? Should we:
A) Keep "(constitutive) character" — our reasoned departure from tradition, acknowledged in TN
B) Use the standard "virtue" for the Laozi block quote specifically (since it IS a quotation of a classical text), then switch to "(constitutive) character" when the author begins their own analysis
C) Something else?

Brief response with your recommendation.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
**B. Use "virtue" for the Laozi block quote, then switch to "(constitutive) character" for the author's analysis.**

This is the right move for three reasons:

1. The Laozi quote is someone else's text. Using an established translation (Lau or Chan) respects the source and gives the reader a recognizable anchor. A reader who has encountered DDJ Ch. 38 before will recognize it; using "character" would make a familiar passage unrecognizable.

2. The switch from "virtue" to "character" is itself philosophically meaningful. It performs the author's argument: the traditional framework uses 德 as "virtue" (moral, top-down, normative), but the author's analysis reveals that 德 actually functions as "character" (constitutive, bottom-up, descriptive). The terminological shift in the English mirrors the conceptual shift the author is demonstrating. The reader *sees* the reinterpretation happen.

3. A brief TN at the transition point does the work: "The author now uses 德 in a broader sense than the traditional 'virtue' -- as (constitutive) character: that which makes a thing what it is. See glossary."

This also resolves any future concerns about departing from established convention -- we are not replacing the standard translation, we are layering the author's reinterpretation on top of it, which is exactly what the essay does.
input.summary: B — "virtue" in Laozi quote, switch to "character" mirrors the author's argument
